speaker: Sophie

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil… Here's your coffee, Sophie.

text: Neil – remember that staff meeting we had yesterday?  Why did you agree to having decaff coffee in the kitchen when I know you don't like it… and neither do I!

text: I know. It's just that the boss said that decaffeinated coffee – that's coffee with the caffeine removed – was a good idea, healthier, you know. And then everyone else agreed. And I… I don't know… I just felt uncomfortable disagreeing with everyone.

text: Well, it's interesting you should say that, Neil. Groupthink is the subject of today's show. Groupthink refers to the type of bad decisions we make when we are in a group. Decisions that are contrary to – or against – what we really think. A psychology experiment conducted in the 1950s showed that a lot of people do exactly that – they submit to the will of the group.

speaker: Neil
text: But before we hear more about this, now would be a good time for today's quiz question. And I get to ask you, Sophie!

speaker: Neil
text: Well, we'll find out later on in the show if that's right or not. Now, the psychologist Solomon Asch is well known for his conformity experiments from the 1950s. Can you tell us what ‘conformity' means please, Sophie?

speaker: Conformity
text: Conformity means behaviour that is the same as the way most other people behave. Asch's main finding was that group pressure can change a person's opinion, of even obvious facts.

speaker: Neil
text: And what did this Asch test involve?

speaker: Sophie
text: 123 male participants were shown a card with a line on it, followed by another card with three lines on it. The participants were then asked to say which line matched the line on the first card in length. The right answer was plain to see, but the participants felt pressurized into saying the wrong answer.

speaker: Neil
text: Why would they do that?

speaker: Sophie
text: Because the majority of people taking part in the experiment had been told to give the wrong answer. Let's hear Professor Nick Chater's explanation. He works at the Warwick Business School here in the UK.

speaker: INSERT
text: Nick Chater, Professor at Warwick Business School, UK

speaker: INSERT
text: By the time it comes to you a whole list of people have said something plainly wrong and you are either going to have to fold and say, 'well, I just agree with them' or you're going to rather uncomfortably say, 'well, I think it's one actually'. And most people, most of the time, tend to fold.

speaker: fold
text: Professor Nick Chater. He uses the word fold, which means you give up. But, Sophie, if people are uncomfortable about supporting the wrong answer, or something they don't believe in, why do they do it?

speaker: going along with
text: Because even though we feel uncomfortable going along with – or agreeing with – something we don't believe, we're even more uncomfortable about disagreeing with the group.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I didn't realize that people were such sheep. I have a will of steel, Sophie.

speaker: will of steel
text: Is that right? So, your will of steel – or strong determination – somehow melted away in the staff meeting yesterday, I suppose?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh well… of course… yes…

speaker: Sophie
text: Let's move on and consider briefly how social media encourages groupthink.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, there's a real danger with something like, for example, the Twitter – the social networking service. Because when an opinion on Twitter starts to “trend”, it can take on a momentum of its own, and people adopt it simply because it's popular, not because they really believe it.

speaker: momentum
text: And momentum means a force that keeps something going once it has started. Let's hear from journalist and author, Jon Ronson. He has an interesting opinion about this.

text: One of the ironies here is that on social media we all like to see ourselves as nonconformists but when we all get together in a group what we're doing is using our individual nonconformity to create a more conformist world. It's like we're defining the boundaries of normality by tearing apart the people on the outside.
